headline: Walmart’s Doug McMillon to Step Down as CEO After Over a Decade
summary: Walmart  said Friday that Chief Executive  Doug McMillon  would step down after over a decade in the role, a change at the top of the country’s largest retailer and private employer as it navigates a complex consumer and government landscape.  John Furner,  current chief executive of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon as CEO after the end of the company’s fiscal year Feb. 1, the company said.  The 51-year-old Furner has served as president and CEO of Walmart U.S. since 2019, overseeing the company’s largest operating segment and more than 4,600 stores.

raw.headline: Walmart’s Doug McMillon to Step Down as CEO After Over a Decade
raw.summary: Walmart  said Friday that Chief Executive  Doug McMillon  would step down after over a decade in the role, a change at the top of the country’s largest retailer and private employer as it navigates a complex consumer and government landscape.  John Furner,  current chief executive of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon as CEO after the end of the company’s fiscal year Feb. 1, the company said.  The 51-year-old Furner has served as president and CEO of Walmart U.S. since 2019, overseeing the company’s largest operating segment and more than 4,600 stores.

headline: Walmart Stock Drops as CEO Doug McMillon Announces Retirement. It’s the End of an Era.
summary: Walmart  stock dropped Friday after the world’s largest retailer announced longtime CEO Doug McMillon was retiring next year.  John Furner, 51, currently serving as CEO of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon, 59, effective Feb. 1, Walmart said.  McMillon will officially retire Jan. 31, but will remain on Walmart’s board of directors until the company’s next annual shareholder meeting to ensure a smooth transition, the company said.

headline: Who Is John Furner? Meet the Walmart Insider Named New CEO
summary: John Furner,  the  Walmart  lifer who was named  Doug McMillon’s  successor as chief executive, has been leading the U.S. arm of the retail behemoth for several years, a role he stepped into just months before the Covid-19 pandemic began.  Furner’s Walmart roots are deep.  In the late 1980s, when Furner was a teenager, his mother, Lana, was diagnosed with breast cancer.

headline: Walmart's Next CEO Gets Analyst Nod
summary: Walmart shares are under pressure after the retailer named John Furner as its next CEO, succeeding Doug McMillon. Telsey Advisory Group's Joe Feldman says not to worry. He calls Furner the logical choice to keep Walmart's momentum going. He joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about what this leadership change means for the stock.

headline: Walmart CEO announces plans to retire in 2026: What to know
summary: Walmart (WMT) CEO Doug McMillon announced his plans to retire at the end of January 2026, to be succeeded in his chief executive role by Walmart US CEO John Furner. Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi asks a panel consisting of Mariner Wealth Advisors chief investment strategist and head of equities Jeff Krumpelman and Yahoo Finance senior reporters Allie Canal and Ines Ferré about their thoughts on the news and what this leadership change means for the retail giant. Walmart is currently scheduled to report quarterly earnings results on Thursday, November 20. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.

headline: Walmart CEO McMillon to Retire in February, US Head Will Take Over
summary: Walmart's CEO Doug McMillon is stepping down marking the end of an era for the world's largest retailer. McMillon, who rose from hourly worker to chief executive, will hand the reins over to the company's US head John Furner. Bloomberg's Emily Cohn leads Bloomberg's consumer team and she joined Bloomberg Open Interest with details on the leadership shake-up.

headline: Toy makers rush into ‘blind box’ trend for holidays following Labubu craze
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -While U.S. consumers keep searching for an authentic Pop Mart Labubu, rivals are introducing their own cheaper, easier-to-find "blind box" products for the key holiday shopping season to capitalize on the craze sparked by the fuzzy mini monsters.  Hot gift lists from retailers like ​Walmart feature a new crop of blind box figurines and trading cards, and U.S. companies including Hasbro and Mattel are selling versions of toys like Furby and Barbie in ‌mystery packaging, incorporating the trend.  A blind box toy – like Spin Master's popular CrystaLynx dragons – generally has packaging that hides the specific product inside so shoppers keep buying until they find the one they want or collect the whole ‌series.
